comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: Douglas AD-7 Skyraider. Modex 511 on engine cowl. Fuselage number 9 with decorative wing like motif . Tail code N of Carrier Air Wing Nine (CVG-9) Light Gull Gray and Insignia White scheme. Wings folded and wheels chocked and two A4D-1 Skyhawks possibly of VA-93 ‘Blue Blazers’ in background. This is a VA-95 ‘Skyknights’ AD-6 Skyraider. From 1957 to 1963 the squadron was named the ‘Skyknights’. From 1963 it became known as the ‘Green Lizards’. From examination of details on this internet webpage reviewing a set of 1/48 scale model decals the aircraft may be identified: modelingmadness.com/scotts/decals/super/72/ss72530.htm 1/48 Microscale Decals 48-306 AD-6 Skyraider VA-65, AD-7 VA-95 AD-6 137629 from VA-65 on USS Shangri-La in 1957, and an AD-7 142030 of VA-95 in 1956. The aircraft may thus be AD-7 142030 of VA-95 as Modex 511. Code N of CVG-9 1956 -1958. 1956 record for VA-95 courtesy of Takafumi Hiroe, citizen of Japan and naval aviation historian: www.gonavy.jp/CVG-CVG9-2.html VA-95 was part of CVG-9 code N assigned to CVA-14 USS Ticonderoga from 1957 to 1958 for two Pacific voyages. Representative color profile of an AD-7 from VA-95 when part of CVG-9 code N assigned to CVA-14 USS Ticonderoga from 1957 to 1958: wp.scn.ru/en/ww3/a/593/3/16#23 (click on picture alongside following text to view profile) Unit: VA-95, CVG-9, US Navy Serial: 508/N (BuNo.142020) Tenth production A-1J - the final Skyraider variant produced. CVA-34 USS Oriskany, circa 1958. After September 1962 the AD-7 was redesignated A-1J. Color profile of A-1J 142030 with a US Navy training squadron: (click on picture alongside following text to view profile) wp.scn.ru/en/ww3/a/593/3/17#158 AD-7 (A-1J) Unit: VA-122, US Navy Serial: 212/NJ (BuNo.142030) NAS Lemoore, circa 1965. The Douglas Skyraider served with the US Navy from the 1950s and flew off aircraft carriers both in peace time and combat during the Vietnam War. After retirement from the US Navy many A-1 Skyraiders were acquired by the US Air Force, for service mainly in South East Asia. They were refurbished and modified with their tailhooks removed, new radio and navigation gear and a YANKEE seat extraction unit installed, plus pneumatic tail wheels. A-1J 142030 was transferred to the USAF as 52-142030. On October 2, 1969 when operating with the 602nd Special Operations Squadron, 56th Special Operations Wing USAF, it tragically crashed and caught fire when the aircraft looped horizontally on takeoff at Nakhon Phanom Royal Thai Air Base, Thailand. The bombs exploded, killing the pilot. Dedicated virtual memorial to the memory of the pilot: www.virtualwall.org/dm/MooreDR02a.htm airforce.togetherweserved.com/usaf/servlet/tws.webapp.Web... "1st Lieutenant Donald R. Moore, Jr., was killed on 2 October 1969 while en route to a search and rescue mission to pick up a downed pilot in Thailand. When taking off, the A-1J aircraft, he was piloting, suddenly veered off course, burst into flames, and crashed. The aircraft's bombs exploded before the pilot could get clear and he was killed." My respect to the pilot his family and friends.
